SharePoint

Style guides and naming conventions for SharePoint

Preface

Partially based on next article

Naming Conventions

1. Project Name

Project name could be:

  • <Company>.<Project or Department>.<Technology>.<Optional subdivision>

In real life it might look like this:

  • Stonebridge.Marketing.SharePoint.EventReceivers

You might not want your company name in the namespace or maybe you want to use a product name in there instead. Some examples:

  • SharePoint.Administration

  • Microsoft.Office.Server.Search

If you are developing an internal framework library, you can omit company name and use platform name instead.

2. Features

When a new feature is created, you will see it listed in your project as Feature1. The title of the feature is named ProjectName + Feature1. In this case, the feature is named SomeCompany.Marketing.SharePoint Feature1. Note, that a space is there between the project name and Feature1.

When you deploy this, the actual folder that gets deployed is named with the name of the project itself and appends an underscore followed by the name of the feature. For example, Visual Studio would name the folder SomeCompany.Marketing.SharePoint_ContentTypes.

Please put a description on your feature.

Viewing the feature in SharePoint, you will see the dot notation in the title and a nice description.

3. Site Columns

Once the column is created, the internal name cannot be changed. Why does this matter? It matters because you want that internal name column to be named consistently with everything else. How should you name it? Do not abbreviate. On top of that, donâ€™t use spaces. As example, you can use site column names such as these:

  • ProductCode

  • Color

  • SatisfactionRating

4. Content Types

Content Types go hand in hand with Site Columns, so we follow the same rules. Avoid abbreviation when naming your content types. Avoid spaces in content type names.

5. Lists

Choosing good names makes finding lists easier. All of the other naming rules apply here, but you should decide on whether you like spaces or not. SharePoint has no issues with you putting spaces in the name of a list or document library. A lot of the default lists such as Shared Documents included in site definitions such as the Team Site have lists with spaces in them.

6. Sites

For sites, I recommend following the same guidelines you do with lists. This simply allows the URLs of sites to be typed in easier. You can make the title whatever you want, just be consistent in the way you set the URL for the site.

Conclusion

You can follow these guidelines but first you should be consistent and follow guidelines and conventions in your project.
